body_html: This also changes the semantics of load_state_dict. Before it replaced the parameters with the ones found in the dict, so you could e.g. send it through a queue to another process, and once it loaded it you would have a model with shared weights. Now, it will only sync them once. I think it's better to keep it the way it worked, because it's probably going to be used more often to resume from checkpoints and sync multiprocessing models. Or we can add an optional copy=True argument.

body: This also changes the semantics of `load_state_dict`. Before it replaced the parameters with the ones found in the dict, so you could e.g. send it through a queue to another process, and once it loaded it you would have a model with shared weights. Now, it will only sync them once. I think it's better to keep it the way it worked, because it's probably going to be used more often to resume from checkpoints and sync multiprocessing models. Or we can add an optional `copy=True` argument.
